description: very nice product. thanks jetbrains
Pretty useless Flatpak right now.
I think the nature of Flatpak and what IntelliJ has to do (such as run Python virtualenvs, etc.) kind of conflict, and this isn't a good fit for a Flatpak. However, it does "kinda" work.

summary: With flatpak it's not usefull. Alot problems with privilages

description: Powerful, with many plugins, probably the best Java & Kotlin IDE.
For the ones that prefer to use a full featured IDE, IntelliJ is without a doubt one of the most complete ones with support for virtually any recent code stack.
Despite the negative comments, it's a pretty good and up-to-date flatpak. I haven't encountered issues, although I installed OpenJDK first.

* regular JDK cannot be referenced, you need to install the JDK via the IDE
* I did not run into major performance hickups that I got with a Snap-powered version of IntelliJ

It can't find the SDKs installed on the system, and adding them in Flatpak shows a lot of shortcomings in Flatpak right now. Not useable for anyone who doesn't want to spend hours hacking things. Just download the one from JetBrains' website.
i want fish shell and my python3.9 not its internal bash shell with python 3.6
InteliJ with flatpak do not see my gtk2 and 3 libraries so javaFX cannot work
JVM code debugging works out-of-the-box but sometimes the IDE hangs when it's lunched upon startup. Overall a good solid experience though. Still trying out the snap version...
I cannot find the files of the installation
Thanks guys. Don`t give up and will stay better
summary: Great app and comfortable for use

description: Installed Flatpack version to Fedora 34 running GNOME. With the flatpak version, editor popups are misaligned unless you switch the IDE's JDK to an oracle distribution which introduces its own set of problems. Additionally if you're developing projects that require docker/programs installed on your local machine you're going to run into problems. Just install the from the Jetbrains site, it's a much smoother experience overall
age rating: early childhood
This flatpak restricts access so you cant use the shell or the JDK

Literally unusable for 99% of development needs because it is a flatpak. Cannot recommend this distribution. 
Download the tar.gz from Jetbrains directly instead.
... as long as you know to install a Flatpak JDK extension. Just search "JDK" in GNOME Software (or your alternative Flatpak store GUI) and install any of them.

When using the flatpak, be sure to install a sdk to get access to java/nodejs/go/php inside the flatpak sandbox. Then add the sdk to the $PATH using flatpak override (/usr/lib/sdk/{sdk}/bin).

Selecting the sdk from within the IDE settings might work for some languages, but others like php will have problems when running unit tests etc..

Possible improvements for the flatpak:
- When starting the flatpak, add the sdks automatically to the $PATH so no flatpak override is needed. 
- Would be great to add some sdks to the optional dependencies so they are shown in gnome software. Most people don't seem to know that they need sdks, and this would probably fix this.
- Look into setting the terminal to the host terminal using flatpak-spawn
- Improve the sandbox, i don't think an ide needs access to my camera or app/discord?
summary: Goode IDE, but needs some setup work

description: Python subprocess calls fail - https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-345756/idea-Flatpak-python-subprocess-call-cant-find-command . Even "Collect Logs and Diagnostic Data from the Help menu." doesn't open the browser.

I had the Problem, where the Terminal in the IDE pointed to the Flatpak-Filesystem, which is unusable for me (and should be for everyone).
If this issue can be addressed, I see no other problem.
summary: Top Software - use non-Flatpak Version instead

summary: Creo que podría mejorar el soporte de typescript

description:
Works fine, no big issues so far.

On the first launch, Intellij tries to create a shortcut which fails. Just uncheck the box to create any shortcut and it will go through. It's not a big deal because Flatpak/Gnome Software will create a launcher anyway.

The only negative side, is that it runs on the built-in Java which at this time is 11, and on my distribution (Arch Linux), `/var/lib/jvm` is not exposed in the flatpak, which makes me unable to run or build apps with newer Java (12,13 and 14 for now)
summary: Works fine - Stuck to embedded JDK11

description: Good for java developpement but it's sure it wouldn't work as it work in windows

I use it at work, in conjunction with SDKMan and since JDK are installed inside the user home directory, I can pick any runtimes I want.

Won't install it otherwise!
